Chemical Engineering Program Texas A&M University at Qatar P.O. 23874 Doha Qatar Graphical abstract The influence of varying Cu atomic ratios in a bimetallic Ni-Cu catalytic system for the CO2 or Dry Reforming of Methane (DRM) is investigated experimentally, in conjunction with ab-initio Density Functional Theory (DFT) and Generalized Power Law Expression (GPLE)-based mathematical modeling approaches. Among the synthesized catalysts, an 8:1 Ni:Cu ratio shows highest activity with stable H2/CO selectivity compared to its monometallic counterpart. Detailed physico-chemical characterization of the catalysts indicate that copper addition minimizes deactivation by forming a Ni-Cu alloy that increases reducibility of the NiO and limits the tendency of the active site toward coke formation. DFT calculations reveal increased energy barrier for carbon adsorption, whilst promoting facile removal of deposited carbon. GPLE analysis of the deactivation profiles suggest coking as the primary deactivation route in monometallic Ni catalyst; although much lesser in extent, deactivation of Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalyst is induced by both sintering and coking regimes. Keywords DRM Ni-Cu alloy DFT Generalized Power Law Expression (GPLE) Bi-metallic catalyst Catalyst deactivation 1 Introduction Research interest in the area of dry (CO2) reforming of methane (DRM) to syngas (a mixture of H2 and CO) is exponentially increasing, as evidenced by the number of papers published each year. A search on Scopus for “Dry CO2 reforming methane” yields a total of 5000+ articles/patents since 1991, with 817 publications on the subject in 2018 alone. An apparent reason for this is DRM’s ability to consume two major greenhouse gases (CO2 and CH4) to produce syngas, from which cleaner fuels via Fisher-Tropsch [1] and value-added chemicals [2] are synthesized. However, a major obstacle towards the large-scale commercialization of this reaction is the highly endothermic nature of the reaction itself [Eq (1)] and is therefore typically performed at very high reaction temperatures, industrially (>800 °C) [3]. Dry Reforming of Methane: (1) CH4 + CO2 → 2H2 + 2CO ΔH0 298K = +247 kJ/mol Another impeding factor for the broader commercialization of this process is the inevitable deactivation of the catalyst via severe carbon deposition (“coke”) and sintering of the active metal phases. Many strategies have been devoted to developing an active and highly stable catalyst for DRM. Although catalysts based on noble metals are superior in terms of activity and durability, their higher price and limited abundance hinder their usage in industrial applications [4]. Therefore, non-noble metals such as Ni and Co-based catalysts are generally preferred for their comparable activity, economical pricing, and higher availability. In particular, Ni-based catalysts are preferred for wide-scale industrial applications [5,6] but suffer from rapid catalyst deactivation due to coke formation, which can block and eventually decrease the number of active sites [7]. In general, carbon formation occurs via methane cracking [Eq (2)] and the Boudouard reaction [Eq (3)]. Methane cracking: (2) CH4 → 2H2 + C ΔH0 298K = +75 kJ/mol. Boudouard reaction: (3) 2CO → CO2 + C ΔH0 298K = −172 kJ/mol. Several approaches have been investigated in a bid to mitigate these problems–variation of the support type, promoters, and method of catalyst synthesis [8–10]. One of the most promising ways of improving the catalytic performance of Ni catalysts is to have Ni alloyed with other metals such as Fe, Co, or Cu [9,11,12]. Cu is relatively inexpensive and is, therefore, an ideal alloying metal. Ni-Cu alloys are currently receiving considerable interest in many chemical reactions, including DRM [13–16]. Cu and Ni have analogous crystal structures - both are face-centered cubic (fcc) metals with very similar lattice constants (3.615 Å for copper and 3.524 Å for Nickel), and can, therefore, form a stable fcc Cu-Ni alloy. A general assumption is that this alloy is homogeneous in composition and is unlikely to form Cu islands on the surface of Ni. However, recent studies have shown that Cu tends to segregate on the surface of the Cu/Ni alloy, depending on the temperature and reaction conditions applied [17–19]. The surface-enrichment with a Cu/Ni alloy is proposed to be the reason why these catalysts exhibit better resistance to carbon deposition [17–21]. For instance, Kitla et al. [20] used H2 chemisorption and CO-DRIFTS spectroscopy to conclude that the surface of Cu/Ni bimetallic particles is strongly enriched by Cu, this surface enrichment by Cu considerably reduces the coking tendency of the Ni-based catalyst. Naghash et al. [22] used XRD, XPS, and Auger measurements to demonstrate the propensity of Cu to segregate as a means to reduce interfacial surface energies. Furthermore, Wang et al. [23] concluded that the surface concentration of Cu in Cu/Ni bimetallic catalysts is higher than in bulk Ni by a factor of 2-3. There are several reports in the literature of similar Ni-Cu catalysts for DRM which, exhibit enhanced catalytic activity and stability compared to mono-metallic Ni catalysts [24–26]. Nataj et al. [27] and Lee et al. [28] observed that the addition of about 1 wt% of Cu to a 10 wt% Ni catalyst led to a highly stable bi-metallic catalyst with greater than 90 % methane conversion compared to a monometallic Ni catalyst. However, Halliche et al. [29] observed the opposite phenomenon wherein Cu addition to Ni/α-Al2O3 system displayed a decrease in activity and an increase in coke deposition. While there are several separate reports on experimental and ab-initio studies on Ni-Cu catalysts for DRM, no investigation till date has combined both approaches to provide comprehensive insight into the reason for their higher activity and the different selectivity performance in terms of H2/CO ratio. In this work, three bi-metallic catalysts with different Ni: Cu atomic ratios were synthesized and tested for DRM activity at 650 °C. At this temperature, both coking and sintering phenomena co-exist, therefore the resultant data is used to describe the effect of Cu on metal sintering and suppression of coke deposition. This ability to resist deposition by carbon is explained via ab-initio Density Functional Theory (DFT) simulations. Furthermore, a Generalized Power Law Expression (GPLE) is implemented to measure the extents of deactivation attributable to sintering and coke deposition on both the Ni-Cu and monometallic catalysts. This combined experimental, DFT, and mathematical deconvolution study of deactivation provides mechanistic insight into the effect of Cu doping and lends credence to the industrial application of these superior bimetallic catalysts over mono-metallic counterparts for the DRM reaction. 2 Methodology 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni (NO3)2.6H2O, Sigma Aldrich) and Copper nitrate hemi (pentahydrate) (Cu (NO3)2 2.5H2O, ACROS) were used as Ni and Cu precursors respectively, and γ-Al2O3 (Sasol Puralox) powder as the support. All reagents were used without further purification. The required amount of Ni (NO3)2 6H2O precursor was dissolved in deionized water, which is equal to the pore volume of support (γ-Al2O3) and then added to support by incipient wetness impregnation to obtain the desired Ni loading (10 wt% Ni). The impregnated support was then transferred into a porcelain crucible and kept in an oven for drying at 110 °C for 12 h in static air. The dried catalyst was calcined in static air at 600 °C for 5 h in a muffle furnace with a temperature ramp of 1 °C/min. For the bimetallic catalysts, the same procedure was followed, bimetallic Ni-Cu/Al2O3 catalysts were also prepared by conventional co-incipient wetness impregnation method. The required amount of both Ni (NO3)2·6H2O and Cu (NO3)2·2.5H2O were used as metal-precursors to obtain a nominal metal (Ni + Cu) loading of 10 wt.%. The Ni: Cu atomic ratio was fixed to 3:1(higher Cu loading), 8:1(medium Cu loading) and 10:1 (Lower Cu loading), respectively. After mixing the precursor aqueous solutions with the γ-Al2O3, the mixtures were then dried at 110 °C for 12 h. The dried catalyst was then subjected to calcination in static air at 600 °C for 5 h in a muffle furnace with a temperature ramp of 1 °C/min. In this report, we have denoted the three bimetallic catalysts as Ni3Cu1/Al2O3 (Ni/Cu atomic ratio = 3/1, ‘high’ Cu loading), Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 (Ni/Cu atomic ratio = 8/1, ‘medium’ Cu loading) and Ni10Cu1/Al2O3 (Ni/Cu atomic ratio = 10/1, ‘low’ Cu loading). 2.2 Characterization The fresh and spent catalysts were characterized with various techniques (BET-SA, H2-TPR, XRD, CO pulse chemisorption, O2-TPO, SEM, TEM, and TGA-DSC) and the technical information can be found in the supplementary information document (ESI-Section1). 2.3 Activity test CO2 reforming of methane was examined in a Microactivity-Efficient benchtop reactor (Micromeritics) using a vertical quartz reactor (i.d. 9 mm) at atmospheric pressure. For tests of catalytic activity and stability, the reaction was carried out at 650 °C for 10 h over 5.5 mg of catalyst and 100 mg SiO2 diluent. 10 % CH4/10 % CO2/80 % He (reactant gas), and hydrogen (reducing gas) were purchased and used as-is from National Industrial Gas Plants, Qatar. Before reaction, the catalyst was reduced in-situ with pure H2 (50 ml min−1) at 650 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, the catalyst was cooled down to the targeted reaction temperature in Helium before the introduction of reactant gas. The composition of reactant gas was (10 %CH4:10 % CO2: 80 %He), and the total flow rate was 30 ml min−1. The effluent gas was online analyzed by a Cirrus 2 Mass spectrometer (MKS Instruments). 2.4 Density functional theory In this section, we clearly outline the methodology employed in the DFT calculations section of the current work. All the calculations reported in this work were performed using the Vienna Ab Initio simulation package (VASP) code [30–33]. Blöchl’s all-electron-like projector augmented wave (PAW) method [34,35] was used to treat the interactions between the ion cores and the valence electrons. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) functional with the revised form of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhoff (RPBE), as revised by Hammer et al., was used to describe the exchange-correlation [36]. The RPBE functional has been observed to be more accurate than the other functionals such as PW91 or PBE in calculating heats of adsorption on nickel for molecules relevant in the reforming reactions [37,38]. The wave functions at each k-point are expanded with a plane-wave basis set with a kinetic energy cut-off of 400 eV. Brillouin zone sampling of the surface slabs was performed using a 3 × 3 × 1 grid generated via the Monkhorst-Pack scheme [39]. The Methfessel-Paxton smearing method of first-order is employed to determine the electron occupancies with a smearing parameter σ of 0.2 eV [40]. The presence of a magnetic element (Ni) in the systems studied in this work warrants the inclusion of the spin polarization effects in these calculations, which are properly addressed in this work. Earlier DFT works on Ni have demonstrated the necessity to account for surface magnetism for an accurate quantitative description of the total energies [41]. The convergence criteria for the electronic degrees of freedom is converged when the energy differences of the consecutive steps in a normal geometry optimization calculation is less than 10−4 eV, whereas for transition state calculation:10-6 eV. The convergence of forces is assumed to be achieved when the forces acting on atoms is less than 0.01 eV/Å in all the calculations. Dimer method [42,43] has been employed to obtain the geometries of transition states. The transition state structures are assumed to be converged if the forces acting on the atoms are all less than 0.01 eV/Å for the various degrees of freedom set in the calculation. The adsorption energy, Eads , is calculated as: (4) Eads = E ( adsorbate / slab ) − Eslab − Eadsorbate where Eadsorbate/slab is the total energy of the slab model with adsorbate; Eslab is the total energy of the bare slab model; Eadsorbate is the total energy of the isolated adsorbate obtained by putting it in a 20 × 20.5 × 21 Å box. In this study, slab models are used to represent the Cu/Ni bimetallic catalyst. The Cu/Ni alloy is represented as a ‘surface alloy,’ motivated by the reported experimental observation (that copper prefers to segregate on the surface in a Cu/Ni system [17–19,44,45]. In this study, the (111) orientation of this lattice was chosen due to its abundance in nickel-based alloys. A four-layer slab with a p(3 × 3) supercell repetition is used to model a Ni (111) surface. To avoid the interactions between the neighboring unit cells, the two z-direction neighbors are separated by a vacuum of approximately 7 layers, which comes to a distance of around 14.25 Å. The Cu/Ni (111) surface alloy was then constructed by replacing varying amounts of nickel atoms with a similar number of copper atoms. Three different Cu-Ni slab models were developed. (a) High coverage CuNi (with 1/9 ML (Monolayer) of Cu on Ni) to represent the high copper content experimental catalyst, Ni3Cu1/Al2O3, (b) Medium coverage of Cu-Ni (with 1/3 ML of Cu on Ni) to represent the medium copper content catalyst, Ni8Cu1/Al2O3, and (c) Low coverage Cu-Ni (1/9 ML coverage of Cu on Ni) to represent the low copper content catalyst, Ni10Cu1/Al2O3. The results on these slab model surfaces are compared with the pure Ni surface. The developed slab models are provided in supplementary information (Figure S1). Unless otherwise specified, the bottom-most layer in the slab models was constrained at its bulk position while the top three layers and its adsorbates were allowed to relax during geometry optimization and transition state (TS) search. 2.5 Measurements of deactivation rates on Ni and Ni-Cu catalysts The generalized power law expression (GPLE) can be used to model the catalyst deactivation regimes such as activity loss due to sintering and coke deposition for different catalytic systems [46–48]. In this work, the GPLE has been applied to compare the catalyst deactivation behavior in the mono-metallic (Ni/γ-Al2O3) and bi-metallic (Ni-Cu/ γ-Al2O3) systems for DRM reaction. The underlying assumptionα in the GPLE model is that the catalyst activity will reach a steady-state activity (SSA) after a long time on stream (TOS) and the activity can be expressed as follow: (5) − d a d t = k d f ( c ) d ( a − a s s ) d where a is the normalized activity, kd is the deactivation constant, d is the order of the deactivation, f(c)d represents the kinetic function that depends on the concentration and ass indicates the SSA. The normalized form of the deactivation equation for first-order GPLE is: (6) a(t) = (1 −ass ) exp(−k 1 t) + ass while for the second deactivation rate: (7) a(t) = (k 2 t + (1 −ass )−1)−1 + ass Quantities assessment of the deactivation caused due to sintering and carbon deposition can be conducted if the activity data fit well to the first or second GPLE [48]. Accordingly, we used the nonlinear least-squares regression in Microsoft Excel to estimate the model parameters. A more detailed discussion on the calculation steps can be found in the supplementary material (ESI, Section 2). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural characterization of fresh catalysts All the fresh calcined catalysts’ textural properties are presented in Table 1 . The bare support γ-Al2O3 has a BET-SA of 153 m2/g and an average pore volume of 0.88 mL/g. In comparison, the metal loaded catalysts have a lower surface area and pore volume compared to bare γ-Al2O3, which could be due to the high metal content (10 wt.%). Ni and Cu particles might block the pores of γ-Al2O3 during metal impregnation, which results in the slight decrease of the pore volume of catalysts. Moreover, when the three bimetallic catalysts Ni10Cu1/Al2O3, Ni8Cu1/Al2O3, and Ni3Cu1/Al2O3 were compared, it was observed that the surface area and the pore volume had very similar values, which makes sense theoretically because the total metal loading was similar in all the catalysts. 3.2 H2-temperature programmed reduction (TPR) Fig. 1 shows the H2-TPR profile of fresh calcined monometallic Ni and Nix-Cu bi-metallic catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3. The monometallic Ni/γ-Al2O3 (Fig. 1(a)) exhibited broad multiple reduction peaks in the range from 500 °C to 800 °C. The low-temperature reduction peak at 570 °C corresponds to NiO weakly interacting with the support (‘bulk NiO’), and the high-temperature range peaks to strongly interacting NiO and NiAl2O4 species. The presence of multiple reduction peaks may be attributed to the presence of different NiOx species produced as a result of varying interactions with γ-Al2O3 [13]. Whereas amongst all the bimetallic Ni-Cu catalysts, the higher Ni: Cu atomic catalyst, i.e., Ni3Cu1/Al2O3, (Fig. 1(d)) exhibits three significant reduction peaks, The peak at relatively low temperature 204 °C can be ascribed to the reduction of bulk CuO [49]; the peak located at 400 °C can be assigned to the reduction of NiO that is strongly interacting with CuO; the reduction peak above 730 °C can be assigned to the reduction of NiAl2O4 species [13]. It is interesting to note that the low-temperature peak at 240 °C in the high Cu-loaded catalyst (Fig. 1(d)) disappears as Cu loading decreases (Fig. 1(b) and(c)), implying the complete incorporation of Cu2+ into the NiO framework via NiCu alloy formation [50,51]. Furthermore, the high-temperature peaks (> 700 °C) in the mono-metallic Ni catalysts appear to have decreased in intensity and shifted to lower temperatures, signifying the effect of Cu addition on decreasing the formation of nickel aluminate spinel. These observations are corroborated with reported literature [52]. The obtained results indicate that the difference in the reduction behavior mainly depends on metal-support interaction and metal-metal interactions in the case of alloys. 3.3 XRD analysis of fresh calcined and reduced catalyst samples XRD patterns of fresh calcined samples are provided in the supplementary information (Figure S2). The XRD pattern of calcined monometallic Ni/γ-Al2O3 has prominent diffraction peaks at 2θ = 37.2°, 45.5°, 60.2°, and 66.6° which can be attributed to a mixture of both NiAl2O4 and γ-Al2O3 phases. The reflections at 2θ = 43.3°, 66.9°, and 75.4° are assigned to the fcc NiO [53,54]. The average crystallite size, as calculated by the Scherrer equation, is 10 nm. The calcined bimetallic NiCu catalysts also show peaks in very similar 2θ positions. However, broader NiO diffraction peaks were also observed at 2θ = 43.3°, 64.3° and 75.3° corresponding to an average crystallite size of 6.5 to 8.4 nm which is lower than that for the monometallic catalyst (Table 1). One possible explanation is that CuO may help stabilize the NiO via the formation of a NiO-CuO solid solution during calcination, thus preventing agglomeration and formation of larger crystallites. Both CuO and NiO have similar lattice structures and can, therefore, readily form a homogenous NiO-CuO solid solution [55,56]. This solid solution subsequently transforms into a Ni-Cu alloy on H2 reduction and plays a crucial role in enhancing the performance as well as the stability of the catalyst. No apparent crystalline phases due to CuO, Cu2O, or other Cu related phases are detected probably due to the copper percentage being lower than the X-ray detection limits, or it might because the particles are in an amorphous state. It is worth noting that the diffraction peak intensities corresponding to NiO (2θ = 43.3°, 64.3°, and 75.3°) decrease while peak intensity at 45.5° increases on increasing Cu addition. This is suggestive of a decrease in bulk NiO and a rise in the formation of NiO-CuO solid solution formation, which in turn stabilizes NiO and prevents the formation of larger crystallites during calcination. XRD patterns of reduced monometallic and bimetallic catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . Reflections at 2θ = 44.4° and 51.7° are attributed to metallic Ni-Cu alloy along with metallic Ni, Al2O3, and NiAl2O4 phases [57]. The Cu modified catalysts have a smaller crystallite size of 7−10 nm, while that of the monometallic catalyst is slightly larger at 11 nm, indicating that Ni-Cu alloy formation during reduction stabilizes the crystallites and minimizes agglomeration. These results also validate the assignment of lower temperature H2-TPR peaks of the Ni-Cu/Al2O3 catalyst to strong Ni-Cu interactions. 3.4 Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) TEM analysis for both Ni/Al2O3 and Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalysts was performed to measure differences in particle sizes between the reduced monometallic Ni and bimetallic catalysts and to confirm the formation of Ni-Cu alloy. Fig. 3 depicts representative TEM, HR-TEM, HAADF-STEM images, and elemental maps of the reduced monometallic Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. Fig. 3(a) shows two kinds of Ni particles, both segregated and well dispersed on the surface. The HR-TEM image of monometallic Ni/Al2O3 (Fig. 3 (b–c))illustrates lattice fringes with an inter-fringe distance of 0.20 and 0.183 nm, corresponding to the (111) and (200) planes of metallic Ni [58]. Ni particle dispersion was also observed by high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) (Fig. 3(d)). A bi-modal particle size distribution plot is observed in Fig. 3(e) alluding to the presence of both smaller, well-dispersed particles as well as larger metal agglomerates. The particles range from 2 to 16 nm in diameter with an average size of 9 nm. In addition, the elemental distribution of Ni and Al, obtained by Energy-Dispersive X-Ray Spectroscopy (EDS) (Fig. 3(f–h)), shows the spatial distribution of Ni particles on the support. Fig. 4 shows representative STEM and HAADF-STEM images for the reduced Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalyst, chosen on account of its higher DRM activity, as described in section 3.6.1. Fig. 4(a–e) illustrates the TEM and HRTEM images of a representative Ni-Cu alloy nanoparticle with an inter-fringe distance of 0.219 and 0.164 nm, corresponding to (111) and (200) planes of Ni-Cu alloy [59,60]. From the frequency-size distribution (Fig. 4(f–g)), it is apparent that the metal particles are in the range of 1 to 8 nm with a mean diameter of 4 nm, which is much lower than for the mono-metallic Ni catalyst. The elemental distribution of Cu and Ni, obtained by Energy-Dispersive X-Ray Spectroscopy (EDS) (Fig. 4(h–j)), shows the overlapping spatial distributions of both Ni and Cu. This is evidence that Cu is completely incorporated into the Ni lattice, resulting in distinct Ni-Cu alloy particles [60], agreeing with XRD results. This observation is significant as it directly affects the electronic properties of the active Ni-Cu center, which in turn enhances the catalytic performance. 3.5 CO chemisorption CO chemisorption was performed to measure the percentage of active sites exposed on the surface in terms of metal dispersion. The metal dispersion is calculated based on the moles of CO consumed to saturate the surface; in addition to summarizing the physicochemical properties of the calcined and reduced catalysts. Table 1 presents the CO chemisorption results of the reduced Ni and Ni-Cu bimetallic catalysts. Contrary to expectations, the monometallic Ni catalyst provided the highest metal dispersion (8 %), while the bimetallic Ni-Cu catalysts showed lower metal dispersions of 2.5 %, 3 %, and 6 %. Since Cu cannot chemisorb CO [49], it is possible that the Cu-Ni alloy formed suppresses CO chemisorption [61]. The dispersion also decreases with increasing Cu content, an anomaly that may be attributed to the segregation of Cu to the surface at higher loadings. These segregated Cu clusters further lower the amount of CO that can be adsorbed, resulting in the abnormally lower estimates for metal dispersion. 3.6 Catalytic performance study for dry reforming of methane The performance of the prepared catalysts was tested for DRM reaction at 650 °C to investigate the effect of Ni/Cu atomic ratio on the activity and stability of bimetallic Ni-Cu/Al2O3 catalysts. The intermediate reaction temperature allows for deactivation via coke formation as well as sintering, which permits investigation into the influence of Cu addition on mitigating them. The apparent reaction rates of CH4 and CO2 (mol/min/gNi) and H2/CO ratio are presented in Fig. 5 (a–c). For the monometallic Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, a higher CH4 conversion rate of 0.125 mol/min/gNi and a CO2 conversion rate of 0.144 mol/min/gNi was observed, with an H2/CO ratio of 0.78. As is typical for DRM, the CO2 conversion rate exceeded that of CH4with the H2/CO ratio < 1. This is expected, since the reverse water gas shift side reaction is also active at this temperature, consuming CO2 and H2 to produce CO and H2O. After 10 h time on stream, the reaction rates declined to 0.08 mol/min/gNi for CH4 and 0.09 mol/min/gNi for CO2. Additionally, the H2/CO ratio dropped to 0.61, signifying a gradual decline in catalyst activity. For Ni reforming catalysts, sintering is typically presumed to occur within the first few hours of reaction, after which the contribution of coking to deactivation exceeds that of sintering. In the case of sintering, weak metal-support interactions and formation of larger particles by atomic or crystallite migration can form larger Ni particles. These larger particles are susceptible to deactivate more severely by carbon formation, since graphitic carbon formation is structure sensitive and occurs readily on crystallites above a critical size [62]. Compared to the mono-metallic Ni catalyst, the addition of Cu has a perceptible effect on catalyst activity. Among the three bi-metallic catalysts prepared, the ‘medium’ Ni/Cu atomic ratio, Ni8Cu1/Al2O3, displayed the highest activity and stability, maintaining almost constant CH4 and CO2 conversion rates of 0.20 and 0.23 mol/min/gNi respectively. The catalyst with the lowest Ni/Cu atomic ratio, Ni10Cu1/Al2O3, maintained a lower CH4 consumption rate of 0.16 mol/min/gNi later declining slightly to 0.14 mol/min/gNi over 10 h Time-onStream (TOS). In addition to a lower rate of deactivation, the bimetallic catalysts with ‘lowest’ and ‘medium’ Cu content exhibited better, and more importantly, stable, H2/CO ratios than the monometallic Ni catalyst. As will be explained in section 3.8, DFT simulations show that the rate of carbon gasification is higher than the rate of formation of surface-adsorbed carbon, producing this stable H2:CO rate. Another reason behind the sustained activity of this ‘medium’ Cu catalyst could be the formation of a Ni-Cu alloy as evidenced from its TPR profile (Fig. 1) and STEM-EDS mapping (Fig. 4) which limits the extent of coking compared to the mono-metallic Ni catalyst. It is worth noting that the TEM results indicate a much lower average particle size for the reduced bimetallic catalyst (Table 1), which indicates improved active phase dispersion and therefore, better coke-resistance. Interestingly, the catalyst with ‘highest’ Cu content, Ni3Cu1/Al2O3 catalyst (Ni:Cu atomic ratio 3:1), showed significantly reduced conversion rates compared to not just the other Ni-Cu catalysts, but even to the monometallic Ni one. A higher amount of copper suppresses DRM catalytic activity almost wholly, an observation also corroborated by previous investigations on Ni-Cu/Al2O3 and Ni-Cu/SiO2 catalysts [28,63]. The excess Cu is likely migrating to the surface due to its lower surface energy compared to Ni, resulting in a Cu-enriched Ni-Cu alloy surface [24]. This surface enrichment may lead to a decrease in the number of Ni sites on the surface that are active for DRM, thus limiting the catalytic activity. Low amounts of Cu dopant (Ni:Cu = 10:1), on the other hand, appear to be insufficient in improving the stability of the Ni catalyst. The quantity of Cu is not enough to mitigate Ni sintering via alloy formation. Thus, unlocking the synergistic effect between Ni and Cu requires careful tuning of the atomic ratios on the surface and not merely within the bulk. The importance of surface-alloy formation is also evident from the 70 -h stability tests, as discussed in the next section. 3.6.1 Catalyst stability test To investigate catalyst stability, the monometallic and the best-performing ‘medium Cu’ Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 bimetallic catalysts were tested for DRM over 70 h at 650 °C. The rates of CH4 and CO2 consumption are presented in Fig. 6 (a, b), while Fig. 6(c) compares the syngas ratio of H2/CO. Significant deactivation is observed on monometallic Ni/Al2O3, with a linear decrease in the CH4 and CO2 conversion rates and H2/CO ratio; as discussed previously, this may likely be due to coke deposition and sintering of the Ni metal particles. After 70 h of DRM reaction, the CH4 conversion rate decreased from an initial 0.12 to 0.012 mol/min/gNi while the CO2 conversion rate decreased from 0.14 to 0.02 mol/min/gNi. In contrast, the bimetallic Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalyst sustained a much higher activity over 70 h, with CH4 and CO2 conversion rates decreasing slightly from 0.20 to 0.16 mol/min/gNi, and 0.21 to 0.17 mol/min/gNi respectively. As discussed earlier, the excellent stability of this Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalyst may be attributed to the smaller particle size and the formation of a Ni-Cu alloy which retards both active metal sintering and carbon formation. It is interesting to note that the H2/CO ratio is nearly constant over 70 h DRM despite the decline in CH4 and CO2 conversion rates; this demonstrates the ability of the bimetallic catalyst to suppress undesired side reactions like the Reverse-Water-Gas-Shift (RWGS) and the coke-forming Boudard reaction. These results once again demonstrate the role of an ‘optimal’ Ni:Cu atomic ratio in keeping the alloy structure intact. As seen from the previous section, an excess of Cu can be counter-productive, as Cu (not active for DRM) can precipitate to the surface during the reaction and lower the presence of exposed Ni. Controlling catalyst synthesis consequently goes a long way in obtaining a surface composition that promotes Ni-Cu synergism, which in turn, minimizes carbon deposition and enhances removal, producing a stable H2/CO ratio. A DFT investigation into the effect of such Ni-Cu surface alloys of specific compositions provides further insight and is discussed in the next section. 3.7 Effect of Ni-Cu alloy formation on suppressing coke 3.7.1 Powder XRD analysis From the X-Ray diffractograms of the spent Ni and ‘medium Cu’ Ni8Cu1 catalysts (Figure S3, ESI), an additional diffraction peak was observed at 2θ = 26.6° for both catalysts, along with the expected reflections. This reflection was assigned to graphitic carbon, accumulated on the surface of the spent catalyst [52]. On comparing the carbon peak intensities, it is obvious that Ni/Al2O3 catalyst deactivated faster as a result of a higher degree of coking than the Ni-Cu catalyst, indicating that the bimetallic Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits better coke resistance than its monometallic counterpart. No attempt was made to measure crystallite size via the Scherrer equation due to a lower signal: noise ratio of the PXRD pattern. Another important observation is that the shape of the characteristic Ni-Cu alloy peak at 2θ = 44.4° remains largely intact, indicating that the Ni-Cu alloy formed is structurally stable. 3.7.2 O2-TPO analysis over coked-catalysts To understand the differences in the nature of carbon formed on the mono and bi-metallic catalysts O2-TPO was performed over the used catalysts after 70 h DRM (Fig. 7 ). The TPO profiles of the catalysts run for 10 h TOS is given in Figure S4. In Fig. 7, the presence of a predominantly graphitic-type of carbon is observed on the monometallic Ni catalyst as evidenced from the intense CO2 peak at 650 °C, produced as a result of the oxidation of deposited coke. Especially in reforming, graphitic forms of deposited carbon typically encapsulate the active metal sites and therefore deactivate them [64]. In the case of the bimetallic catalysts, the TPO curve peaks at a much lower 590 °C, due to the lower energy required for oxidation. This indicated that the type of carbon formed in the bimetallic catalyst is predominantly amorphous (filamentous/polymeric) and is highly reactive. Furthermore, the amount of coke accumulated in the spent Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 is notably lower than in the spent Ni/Al2O3, as inferred from the areas under the TPO curves. The rate of coking for the monometallic catalyst is 1.19E-03 mg C/h/gcat, much higher than for the bimetallic catalyst at 4.21E-04 mg C/h/gcat. This indicates that Cu plays a vital role in effectively minimizing coke formation. These results agree well with the XRD analysis of the spent catalysts. 3.7.3 TEM and SEM analysis To further investigate the morphology and the nature of carbon formed on the used catalysts, TEM analysis was performed on monometallic Ni/Al2O3 and ‘medium Cu’ bimetallic Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalysts after 10 h DRM reaction (Figs. 8 and 9 ). Various forms of carbon are seen deposited on the surface of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 8(a, b)): multi-walled carbon nanotubes, nano-onions, and other filamentous structures. Of the nanotubes formed, some of them had Ni particles at the tip or embedded within the closed-end tube, while the others lacked any apparent Ni crystallite. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) keep growing from the Ni surface resulting in the degradation of the active structure and eventually lead to total deactivation of the catalyst [65]. While CNTs do not immediately lead to catalyst deactivation, graphitic forms of carbon cause rapid deactivation by encapsulating active sites. A representative HR-TEM image in Fig. 8(c) clearly shows a Ni particle entrapped in the encapsulating carbon onion. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) image (Fig. 8(d)) further highlights Ni particles, identified as bright spots, trapped either within graphitic carbon nano-onions or in CNTs. Calculating the average Ni particle size from TEM indicates that the Ni size was left mostly intact, with only a slight increase from 9 to 9.4 nm. It has been reported that the primary reason for the deactivation of a Ni/Al2O3 catalyst is carbon deposition during DRM on the catalyst surface [66]. Scanning-transmission electron microscope high-angle annular dark-field (STEM-HAADF) image of Ni, Al, and C clearly shows (Fig. 8(e–g)) how carbon deposition detaches Ni particles from the support either via CNT growth or via graphitic carbon encapsulation. The overlaid EDS images of Ni, Al, and C are shown in Fig. 8(h). Fig. 9(a) shows a representative TEM image of ‘medium Cu’ bimetallic Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalyst. Interestingly, except for some amorphous carbon, neither CNTs nor encapsulating graphitic carbon forms were observed on the bi-metallic catalyst even after 10 h of the DRM reaction. It is likely that the carbon, initially deposited on the bimetallic surface, is active and readily oxidized by CO2 via a lower energy pathway [67]. The carbon thus formed is expected to be amorphous, minimizing the formation of structured graphitic carbon, which can deactivate the catalyst. The HR-TEM images (Fig. 9(b–c)) also validate the homogeneous, alloy nature of the dispersed Ni-Cu nanoparticles. A lattice fringe spacing of 0.21 is measured for the active particle, consistent with (111) planes of Ni-Cu alloys [59]. After 10 h of DRM reaction, this inter-fringe distance remains the same (Fig. 9(c)), indicating that the Ni-Cu alloy is intact and plays a critical role in suppressing the coke formation specifically the formation of graphene-like layers that eventually lead to CNTs and encapsulating carbon nano-onions [68]. Scanning-transmission electron microscope high-angle annular dark-field (STEM-HAADF) image of the used Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 (Fig. 9(d)) reveals particles in the range of 2–14 nm (mean - 7.2 nm), indicating that the Ni particle grew from 4 to 7.2 nm after DRM reaction. These results strongly suggest particle sintering as the primary contributor to deactivation, as opposed to significant carbon deposition in the mono-metallic Ni catalyst. STEM-HAADF image of Cu and Ni and the overlaid image (Fig. 9(e–h)) reveal that the Cu and Ni atoms comprising the active nanoparticles were homogeneously dispersed and supports the formation of the Ni-Cu alloy phase. These results strongly suggest that the Ni-Cu alloy nanoparticles were formed with high phase purities, which is consistent with the XRD results. The overlaid STEM-HAADF images of Ni and Cu (Fig. 9(h)) coincide well with each other further confirming the retention of the Ni-Cu alloyed phase even after the DRM reaction. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) analysis has been performed over the fresh (Figure S5) and deactivated catalysts (Figure S6). Both the supported monometallic and bimetallic fresh, calcined catalysts exhibit similar morphological features and as such were indistinguishable from each other. However, after 70 h TOS activity and durability test at 650 °C, there are obvious differences in the morphologies in the used catalysts. Figure S6(a) shows the SEM images of used monometallic Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, exhibiting a large amount of coke deposition in the form of carbon nanofibers/CNTs. The CNTs, in combination with graphitic carbon (not seen in the figure), produce catalyst deactivation with time on stream via gradual encapsulation of the Ni active sites, and pore–blockage. These forms of carbon require higher temperatures to be oxidized, as evidenced by O2-TPO, implying they are more recalcitrant, and therefore cause faster deactivation. On the other hand, the SEM micrograph of the bimetallic Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalyst (Figure S6(b)) indicates that coverage of the catalyst by carbon has occurred to a much lower extent. On the surface is what appears to be a more amorphous type of carbon, which is more reactive and can be eliminated readily. These findings correlate well with the conclusions drawn from XRD and O2-TPO analysis. 3.7.4 TGA-DSC analysis of spent catalyst To quantify the coke formed on the used catalysts and identify the nature of carbon present, ThermoGravimetric Analysis (TGA), coupled with Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC), was performed. Fig. 10 (a) displays the TGA profiles of the used monometallic Ni/Al2O3 and bimetallic Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalysts after 10 h of DRM at 650 °C. As discussed in section 3.7.2, the temperature required for oxidation corresponds to the type of carbon species involved, and DSC provides this information in terms of heat flow per gram sample as a function of temperature (W/g°C, Fig. 10(b)). Based on the literature, the carbon forms may be classified in terms of oxidation temperature as (a) highly reactive activated carbon species that oxidize at low temperatures (<350 °C); (b) the amorphous carbon and carbon nano-filaments/fibers/CNTs that oxidize between 350−550 °C; and (c) non-reactive graphitic carbon species that oxidize at higher temperatures of >650 °C [27,69]. As depicted in Fig. 10(a), the monometallic Ni/Al2O3 catalyst shows a significant weight loss (43 %) in the range of 550−700 °C, probably due to oxidation of both filamentous and non-reactive graphitic carbon, which severely degrade catalyst performance. In contrast, the bimetallic Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalysts display a much lower weight loss of 6.4 %, suggesting that the quantity of filamentous and graphitic carbon formed is minimal, in agreement with XRD and O2-TPO results. It has been demonstrated that a catalyst with smaller metal-particles and higher dispersion typically possess stronger metal-support interactions [70,71], which minimizes coke deposition. These results are consistent with the SEM results shown in Figure S6. Fig. 10(b)presents the DSC profiles of the used Ni/Al2O3 and Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalyst after 10 h of DRM reaction. Contrary to its TPO profile, the monometallic Ni/Al2O3 displays two exotherm peaks - one at 636 °C and the other at 707 °C, indicating that at least two types of carbon species were formed. The stronger exotherm at 636 °C may be assigned to the oxidation of filamentous carbon, and the peak at the higher 706 °C might be due to oxidation of graphitic carbon [66,67,72]. This temperature range overlaps relatively well with that observed via TGA. The bimetallic Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalyst, on the other hand, has a single exothermic peak at an intermediate temperature of 675 °C, likely corresponding to the oxidation of a combination of amorphous and filamentous carbon. These results are in good agreement with the SEM and O2-TPO analysis. By this point, it is quite apparent that the bimetallic Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalyst is relatively more stable than its mono-metallic counterpart, able to impede coke deposition significantly via the addition of a small amount of Cu. This analysis is further validated in the next sections via ab-intio DFT simulations as well as computational modeling of the catalyst deactivation profile. 3.8 Investigating the role of Cu on the bimetallic Ni-Cu system via density functional theory calculations In the current work, DFT calculations have been used to gain insights into the enhanced catalytic activity of Ni/Cu alloy bimetallic catalysts. The adsorption of carbon on the surface slab models with varying amounts of copper is studied as a first step. Adsorption energies of the reaction intermediates on a particular catalytic surface quantify the affinity of this intermediate towards this surface. In particular, the C adsorption energy on a specific surface could be used to evaluate the affinity for coke formation of this surface. A lower C adsorption energy on a catalyst surface implies a lower surface coverage of C from a thermodynamic point of view. Therefore, it can be claimed that this surface leads to a lower tendency for carbon deposition and improvement of the coke resistance of the catalyst. Table 2 lists the adsorption energies of carbon on various surfaces as well as the most stable adsorption sites. It was observed that the carbon atom preferred to adsorb on the three-fold hollow sites. According to the definition used to calculate adsorption energies, more negative adsorption energy implies stronger adsorption of the intermediate to the surface. Stronger adsorption of carbon, therefore, implies that the surface has a higher tendency for coke deposition. As can be seen from Table 2, carbon adsorbs most strongly on the monometallic (pure) Ni (111) surface with an adsorption energy of -7.50 eV, indicating its higher tendency towards coke deposition. We observe that as the amount of copper dopant amount increases, the carbon adsorption energies (in other words, the coking tendency of a particular surface) decreases from -6.98 eV for the low copper loading catalyst to -5.62 eV for high-copper loading catalyst. Thus, as far as the coking affinity of the surface is concerned, the surface with 1.0 ML copper coverage (high copper loading) is observed to have the least tendency for coking amongst all catalysts studied with a carbon adsorption energy of only -5.62 eV. These favorable carbon adsorption energies provided the impetus to investigate activation barriers for the step-wise dehydrogenation of methane in the DRM reaction. Fig. 11 compares the reaction energy profile for the steps involved in CH4 dehydrogenation on a pure nickel surface to that of the high Cu loading (1.0 ML) and medium Cu loading (1/3 ML) systems. As can be seen from the figure, the reaction energy barriers for the dehydrogenation steps are prohibitively high for the DRM reaction to sustainably proceed for long reaction times. In the case of pure Ni and ‘medium’ Cu-loaded systems, the relative barriers of all intermediates such as CH3*+H*, CH2*+2H*, CH*+3H*, and C*+4H* are of the order of 0.5–1.0 eV. In contrast, the relative energy barriers of these intermediates on the high Cu loading system is much more endothermic, of the order of ∼2.0–4.0 eV. Thus, while Table 2 may indicate that the high Cu loading is better in terms of resisting carbon formation, the activation barriers for CH4 dehydrogenation on this system (shown in Fig. 11) are relatively very high that it is rather difficult for the reaction to proceed. We also observe from this figure that the activation barriers for the step-wise dehydrogenation of methane in the case of 1/3 ML medium copper loading are very comparable to those of pure Ni. Moreover, while the individual barriers for CH4 dehydrogenation are high enough to reduce the total amount of carbon that can be deposited, they are not high enough for the reaction to not proceed. Of particular interest in the medium Cu loading of 1/3 ML is the activation barriers for the carbon formation as well as carbon ‘elimination’ or gasification (to CO) reactions. The activation barriers for carbon formation reaction through CH dissociation CH* → C* + H* are plotted for the ‘medium Cu’ system in Fig. 12 (a) and carbon elimination via oxidation with oxygen to form CO, C* + O* → CO* in Fig. 12(b). In both of these figures, we have not included the barriers for the ‘high Cu’ coverage system. The reason for this is the extremely thermodynamically unfavorable nature of CH intermediate, as can be observed from Fig. 12. Similarly, the barrier for C gasification is too high for this reaction to proceed. From the Fig. 12(a), we see that the activation barrier for CH* dissociation reaction to form atomic carbon and hydrogen is of the order of 1.41 and 1.45 eV for the pure Nickel system and ‘low Cu’ coverage system, respectively. For the system with ‘medium’ coverage of Cu, the barrier for carbon formation is increased to 1.89 eV, a significant increase of almost 0.45 eV. As the final step in the dehydrogenation of methane, the dissociation of CH to elemental C is expected to be the major contributor toward catalyst deactivation by coking. Thus, it can be concluded from the DFT calculations of Cu-Ni slab models that the activation barrier for carbon formation on ‘medium’ coverage Cu-Ni is considerably increased, rendering it comparatively difficult for carbon deposition to take place on this system. Similarly, in Fig. 12(b), the barriers for carbon elimination via gasification from the surface oxidation with O2 to form CO is depicted for pure, ‘low’ and ‘medium’ coverage systems. It is observed that the barrier for carbon elimination is considerably lowered to 0.53 eV for medium Cu doped system when compared to low Thus, carbon formation (via the dehydrogenation of methane) is suppressed on Cu/Ni surfaces, while the capacity for carbon gasification to CO is enhanced considerably. This observation is in line with previous DFT studies on Cu/Ni bimetallic catalysts [73–75]. In their work, Zhang et al. [73] modeled two types of Cu/Ni catalysts: (1) Homogeneous (1:1) Cu/Ni system and (2) surface Cu enriched (segregated) Cu/Ni system. They have observed that carbon deposition is inhibited, and carbon elimination accelerated on segregated Cu/Ni bimetallic alloy. Previously, Liu et al. [74,75] have shown that carbon formation through CH4 dissociation is suppressed on segregated CuNi(111), but promoted on homogeneous CuNi(111). These results, in conjunction with those of the current study, imply that not only is the amount of copper important in minimizing coke deposition but the specific structural arrangement of Ni and Cu on the surface, which promotes synergistic Ni-Cu interaction. Having established the existence of Cu/Ni experimentally by TPR, STEM, and XRD in the catalyst, DFT goes a step further to provide atomistic-level insight into how Cu addition promotes carbon removal, while simultaneously minimizing carbon deposition – which is the objective of the investigation. In summary, DFT demonstrates that increasing Cu loading produces a trend in catalytic activity. Adding 1/9 ML Cu (“low Cu”) has a negligible effect on carbon deposition and removal to CO, compared to the pure Ni surface. On the other hand, higher Cu loading (1 ML) prevents C deposition as it retards CH4 dehydrogenation, meaning, DRM cannot proceed favorably on this surface. Thus, DFT calculations can indicate precisely why the ‘medium Cu’ sample (Ni:Cu-8:1) is a better compromise between the low and high Cu loaded systems. 3.9 Measuring the extents of sintering/coking via deactivation profile modeling To provide a quantitative assessment of the respective contributions of metal sintering and coking to the deactivation of the mono- and ‘medium Cu’ bi-metallic catalyst, the normalized activity data for 70 h TOS is modeled using the fitting parameters from the GPLE, as described in the supplementary information. For the mono-metallic Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, both the first and second-order GPLEs fit the experimental deactivation data quite well with R2 values of 0.98 and 0.81, respectively (Table S1). The calculated catalyst steady-state activity, ass approaches almost zero, given an infinite amount of time-on-stream for both first and second-order GPLE models (Figure S7(a)). This goes against the primary requirement in GPLE fitting that the deactivation must be asymptotic and should not reach a zero value. In this specific scenario, ass tends to zero, most probably due to the high rate of the carbon deposition, which eventually covers the catalyst surface, preventing accessibility of the reactants to the active site. For the “medium” Cu bimetallic Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalyst (Figure S7(b)), the ass value calculated using the second-order GPLE model for a similar TOS of 70 h was found to be at a much higher 0.615. The αααααα value predicted by the second-order GPLE model is considerably lower than the ass value of 0.725 (Table S1) calculated by the first-order model. Comparing both first and second-order fitting trends, it is apparent that the second-order model is more realistic in predicting ass value, as previously reported for other catalytic systems [48]. Having confirmed the applicability of the GPLE to model the experimental deactivation profile, the next step was to de-convolute the total deactivation into that caused by sintering and coking, respectively. From a visual appraisal of the experimental deactivation profile, it is readily evident that deactivation in the monometallic catalyst is controlled differently compared to the bi-metallic catalytic system. Therefore deconvolution was performed following the method described by Argyle et al. [48]. Fig. 13 depicts the loss of total activity as well as the fractional contribution of sintering (f 1) and coking (f 2) to the total loss via deactivation (ftot ) for monometallic and bimetallic catalyst over 70 h TOS. For the monometallic Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, the model results suggest that sintering is the dominant mode of deactivation initially, but declines to negligible values within a few hours, being surpassed by carbon deposition which ends up contributing up to >95 % (Table 3 ) of the total deactivation. These results are corroborated by the TEM, TPO and TGA analysis of the spent catalyst, as discussed in section 3.7. Attempts to determine the sintering of the catalyst in terms of dispersion loss using CO chemisorption were unsuccessful for both the mono and bimetallic spent catalysts, and so, cannot be used to validate the models’ results. In contrast to the monometallic catalyst, the deconvolution of the deactivation profile of the bimetallic Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalyst shows that nearly 23 % (Table 3) of the total deactivation loss is due sintering even after 70 h TOS. One has to remember that these numbers correspond to a fraction of the total deactivation which is still far lesser for the bi-metallic catalyst. Wu. et al. [59]observes that the addition of Cu promotes the sintering resistance of a bimetallic Ni-Cu catalyst supported on silica nano-sheets. This is in contrast to the current study, wherein the modeling results are suggestive of a higher sintering contribution to the deactivation of the Ni-Cu bimetallic catalyst. However, the sintering occurs to a relatively lesser degree and, from experimental testing, does not appear to impact the overall catalyst activity significantly. 4 Conclusions The addition of an appropriate amount of Cu into Ni-Cu bimetallic catalyst affords significantly improved activity (0.17 mol/min/gNi) when compared to their monometallic Ni/Al2O3 counterpart (0.012 mol/min/gNi). Additionally, the ‘medium’ Cu bimetallic catalyst yields a stable H2/CO ratio of ∼0.9 even when the activity begins to decline, while the ratio decreased rapidly for the monometallic catalyst, reaching 0.35 at the end of 70 h time on stream. Catalyst characterization by TPR reveals that Cu increases the reducibility of Ni, while XRD and TEM validate the formation of smaller bi-metallic crystallites (4 nm vs. 9 nm avg. crystallite size for monometallic Ni) and the formation of a Ni-Cu alloy. CO chemisorption indicates lower dispersion for the bimetallic catalysts, attributed to Cu’s inhibitory effect on CO adsorption. TEM results, on the other hand, show a greater dispersion for the bimetallic catalyst. XRD, TPO, SEM and TGA-DSC analysis of used catalysts confirm that the monometallic Ni deactivated rapidly primarily due to a large amount of graphitic carbon formation. In contrast, the ‘medium’ Cu loaded Ni8Cu1 catalyst produced a more amorphous or ‘active’ form of carbon, with minimal graphitic carbon formation. The experimental evidence is well supported by ab-initio DFT simulations of carbon deposition on mono-metallic Ni and bi-metallic Ni-Cu surfaces. From DFT, it is observed that the addition of Cu increases the activation energy barriers for CHx dehydrogenation to C by nearly 1.5 times and considerably decreases activation energy barrier for carbon elimination through carbon gasification for medium Cu doped system when compared to the low Cu doped system and pure Ni system. Furthermore, these results are consistent with catalyst deactivation modeling studies carried out by using the Generalized Power Law Expression. The results indicate that the rapid deactivation of the monometallic Ni catalyst is primarily due to significant coke formation whereas, the medium Cu loaded Ni8Cu1 catalyst experienced minimal deactivation owing to a higher degree of particle sintering in the initial phases, later balanced out by coke formation. The combined computational and experimental analysis presented indicate that the percent of Cu present and, more importantly, the surface arrangement of Ni and Cu atoms, i.e., surface composition, are critical for ‘optimal’ performance for DRM. The Cu content has to be high enough to allow alloying with Ni, but not high to point where excess Cu segregates and forms independent clusters on the surface of the catalyst. The combination of detailed experimental investigation and theoretical calculations in this work opens up further possibilities in the use of bi-metallic catalysts for the dry reforming of methane reaction. coredata.dc:description: The influence of varying Cu atomic ratios in a bimetallic Ni-Cu catalytic system for the CO2 or Dry Reforming of Methane (DRM) is investigated experimentally, in conjunction with ab-initio Density Functional Theory (DFT) and Generalized Power Law Expression (GPLE)-based mathematical modeling approaches. Among the synthesized catalysts, an 8:1 Ni:Cu ratio shows highest activity with stable H2/CO selectivity compared to its monometallic counterpart. Detailed physico-chemical characterization of the catalysts indicate that copper addition minimizes deactivation by forming a Ni-Cu alloy that increases reducibility of the NiO and limits the tendency of the active site toward coke formation. DFT calculations reveal increased energy barrier for carbon adsorption, whilst promoting facile removal of deposited carbon. GPLE analysis of the deactivation profiles suggest coking as the primary deactivation route in monometallic Ni catalyst; although much lesser in extent, deactivation of Ni8Cu1/Al2O3 catalyst is induced by both sintering and coking regimes.

coredata.dc:title: An experimental and first principles DFT investigation on the effect of Cu addition to Ni/Al2O3 catalyst for the dry reforming of methane
